column39: Please indicate how often these challenges arise in your team. [“Not my job”-mentalityPeople that refuse to take on or help with tasks that are outside of their role or were not explicitly assigned to them during the planning process. Includes situations in which team members stumble across an issue that was not their responsibility, but they could fix with relative ease, yet they choose not to.]
column40: Please indicate how often these challenges arise in your team. [Different communication preferencesClashing preferences of how synchronization should happen(chat, mail, voice calls, video calls, in-person meetings, via documentation/planning tools) leading to people being upset over the chosen mode or planning being delayed or obstructed due to unmotivated participation.]
column41: Please indicate how often these challenges arise in your team. [Destructive CompetitionPeople that put their own personal gain above the common goal. Prestigious tasks are not assigned to the most competent person but out of political reasons. (Representatives of departments refusing to cooperate or even manipulating others to profit personally).]
column42: Please indicate how often these challenges arise in your team. [Lack of ConfidencePeople that systematically underestimate their potential, thus avoiding challenging tasks and potentially limiting their own growth.]
column43: Please indicate how often these challenges arise in your team. [Over-ConfidencePeople that systematically overestimate their current skill and knowledge, leading (for example) to incorrect time or budget estimates.]
column44: Please indicate how often these challenges arise in your team. [Lack of EmpathyPeople without a sense of how those around them feel or without a will to adapt to the emotional state of colleagues. Examples: Anxious colleague is yelled at for not being able to complete a task instead of supported. Emotional unrest is not recognized and no support offered by superiors or colleagues.]
column45: Please indicate how often these challenges arise in your team. [PressurePeople being pressured to be more productive using forceful communication (yelling, belittling, needlessly pointing out deadlines) instead of jointly looking for ways or getting additional resources to improve the situation.]
column46: Please indicate how often these challenges arise in your team. [People not reporting problems in timePeople not requesting assistance or not reporting a blocking problem immediately, potentially pretending there is no problem as to not lose face, potentially endangering financial or time constraints.]
column47: Please indicate how often these challenges arise in your team. [Frequently changing team membersThe teams are often recomposed and workers have to work with and adapt to new team members.]
column48: Please indicate how often these challenges arise in your team. [Aggressive Discussion StylesPeople that use shouting, yelling and general aggressive verbal modes, or try to allocate a lot of speaking time for themselves, while not giving room to speak for less dominant colleagues.]
column49: Please indicate how often these challenges arise in your team. [MisunderstandingsThe intended meaning is not transferred accurately over the selected communication channel. This could be due to bad pronunciation, language barriers, technical issues, use of sarcasm/irony, leaving out details because it is assumed it is already known etc.]
column50: Please indicate how often these challenges arise in your team. [Discussions are not solution-orientedDiscussions or meetings often either become off-topic or are not aimed towards finding an actual solution, but rather used as a vent to complain about circumstances.]
column51: Please indicate how often these challenges arise in your team. [Reluctance to change working habitsStaff are reluctant to try out new infrastructure, processes or tools and would rather stick to the established, even if it is known to perform worse.]
column52: Please indicate how often these challenges arise in your team. [Team is not kept up-to-dateUpdates regarding the project, the team’s or company’s vision, problems and goals or staff changes are not communicated clearly and/or in time.]
column53: Please indicate how often these challenges arise in your team. [Lack of mentorsDelays occur as there is no designated person to contact in case of technical issues or lack of knowledge about company procedures.]
column54: Please indicate how often these challenges arise in your team. [Missing team cohesionThere is no feeling of being a “closely knit” team, with its members supporting each other technically and emotionally and being interested in each other’s tasks.]
column55: Please indicate how often these challenges arise in your team. [Different needs of staff not respectedThe working environment does not cater to individual needs and requests for individual changes are not respected by the management, leading to colleagues feeling unhappy about the place they work in. Examples: Standing desks are denied. People are forced to work in open space offices.]
column56: Please indicate how often these challenges arise in your team. [NegativityA general sense of negativity lingers, causing demotivation and rants rather than a productive spirit of problem solving.]
column57: Please indicate how often these challenges arise in your team. [HarassmentPeople harassing colleagues, including insults, threats, belittling, lack of respect, racism and sexism.]
column58: Please indicate how often these challenges arise in your team. [Missing appreciationSuperiors or colleagues rarely acknowledge the work behind a successful task, or the sacrifices individual staff made to make something possible.]
column59: Please indicate how often these challenges arise in your team. [Lack of mediation in conflictsPersonal disputes linger on for a long time, potentially disrupting productivity, as there is no procedure or responsible person to mediate the two opposing parties.]
column60: Please indicate how often these challenges arise. [Bad Work-Life-BalanceUnmitigated fatigue leading to less productivity during workhours.]
column61: Please indicate how often these challenges arise. [Work is not solution-orientedA lot of time is spent on work that does not add to the solution, but is necessary to meet a certain (potentially emotional) expectation. Example: A certain style of code is required even though the delivered code meets quality and maintainability standards. An unsuitable framework is used because a team lead prefers it.]
column62: Please indicate how often these challenges arise. [Tasks insufficiently analyzedThe complexity and requirements of a task were not explored well enough, thus leading to an incorrect time assessment or lack of required knowledge to solve it well and in time.]
column63: Please indicate how often these challenges arise. [Task is not well defined or explainedTasks are often not explained sufficiently, leave too much room for interpretation, possibly leading to unnecessary or wrong implementations that need to be revised later on.]
column64: Please indicate how often these challenges arise. [Lack of knowledgeThe assigned tasks require far more expertise than the assignee has. While a challenging task can lead to growth, a task that is too difficult can hinder learning.]
column65: Please indicate how often these challenges arise. [Gold PlatingTasks are “overdone” and more functionality than required by the task or client is added.]
column66: Please indicate how often these challenges arise. [DemotivationTime is wasted and procrastination occurs as there is a feeling of not wanting to work on specific tasks.]
column67: Do you have any additional challenges to report?
column68: Do you have any feedback or remarks about the survey?

column35: Very successfully

column67: What to do to improve unsatisfactory state? If any ;)

When requirements were given by the client to the team lead and were distributed to the team members, everything was told verbally. Requirements were not elicited properly and was rarely given in a written format  which often led to misunderstandings  as to weather the done task was discussed or not.

column35: Conference with video and zoom integration, open slack channels to drop-in and discuss any topic
column37: Fluid and prompt discussions

column35: We use Slack's threading feature extensively, this helps a lot for people on disparate projects to keep up on what is happening without being swarmed by details if they don't need it.
column37: It helped us write down what is expected more. Previously it was all very much up-in-the-air and person-to-person communication, which is terrible for teamwork.

column67: Time is a big factor since i work in a small company and teams change, not to mention people change with time as well. Also, based on the project and the clients, the experience of working in the same team can also change.
column68: The survey is much shorter this time and hence I completed it haha. All in all, many appropriate questions were asked.

column67: working completely from remote makes it impossible to look into the face of a colleague before starting communication explicitely

column35: We use the latest tools available and regularly align on the way we will use them.
column37: The result is a functional team. Without successful communication, there is no SW team.
column67: I like to relax in the coffee corner with my colleagues when in the office. When we communicate over different tools it is usually just about work.
column68: Some of the questions look like they were translated from German to English. I have not heard that any SW team uses VR tools so far. My team is working in the home office due to the Corona situation, but even when in the office we used the same tools. Some questions suggest that the tools are used differently when in-home office which is not the case.

column34: My offsure team native language is not english only half of the team speaks english. I work as a product owner and the meetings always takes so long every critical aspect needs to be translated to the team native language. Sometimes I feel really like lost in translation.
column36: I think it is not team fault its the setup we have they should have a PO that knows direclty their native language.
column67: We have one developer that has a superhero complex. He has issues not being a team player which makes it hard to communicate with or reason with as a product owner.

column35: Video+Audio calls are established within the company culture. Issues where not that much communication is needed, are usually solved by chat.
column37: No major impact after everyone changed to working from home.
column67: The team worked together in the native language and then needed to adapt to speak English. This resulted in communication difficulties for certain team members.

column35: We use Slack for chat, spontaneous or scheduled video confs on Hangout for discussions. We write concepts into Confluence/Slides and track issues in JIRA in an agile setup. In person meetings are mostly socialising and less deep discussions. We use github for central development and code sharing (or Gitlab), with customers.
column37: As an architect there is more overhead as you cannot just walk into someone's office and discuss concepts. So you need to write concepts first and propose them (e.g. using process like PEP from Python). You need to think more strategically to whom, when to share information to get a concept though. Also you need to plan your time and the other person's time. You can not expect someone else has time, they might be just busy with other things.
column67: Lack of human socialising. See https://about.gitlab.com/company/culture/all-remote/informal-communication/
column68: Async text based tools are also "JIRA issues"

column35: Slack for everything
column37: Always being aligned as a team

column35: Communication platforms are standardised across the company so meetings, trainings, alerting and casual meetups are easily accessible and fully understood by the users in our teams. Departments, teams, and channels help organise the employees but doesn't create silos (no permissions to access/post in different groups). We notify each other within the team as if we were in the same office for example small breaks day start and day end, we also sing birthdays for team members and organise coffee breaks for casual talks or events like a virtual Octoberfest :)
column37: We track changes in team communication and since we moved to full remote the communication indicators went up by almost 10% across the board. Other indicators followed suite, trust between team members and collaboration as well as satisfaction stress levels and workplace happiness. Delivery and quality went up as a result.

column35: By actively working around COVID restrictions via Webex and e-mail, plus platforms to manage tasks and commits.
column37: Fluid development process with few questions left unanswered.

column68: It was quite short, and made me realize we're doing great at work.

column34: Before the pandemic we were regularly sent to the other team's location for meetings that could have been done as videoconferences.  During the pandemic we finally switched to videoconferences but I fear we will be sent on business trips again soon. (I answered the above questions for the time before the pandemic, as the questions didn't specify which you wanted.)
column36: Some team members left our company because they didn't like the regular multi-day business trips.
column67: What has happened frequently - and why I am leaving - is that the people who play foosball / smoke are involved in project discussion, whereas anyone who doesn't do both is left out and only informed afterwards of decisions.  Very top-down from the lead developer / project manager.  It is a distinct disadvantage of in-person and on-site communication that happens with those people who aren't at those informal interactions are left out.  And no, I don't plan to take up either foosball or smoking!

column67: One big challenge is to remain motivated when the job at hand represents no real challenges. When mots of the time it's the same old set of things you've done in the past.

column35: Video calls sharing screen to emulate two or more peaople working on the same computer. Also asynchronous communication via issue tracking apps and code review tools integrated in the VCS software server.
column37: I can work remotely, saving commute time and energy, thus improving all team's work/life balance. We are forced to write more, so it's easier to keep track of decisions and it enforces asynchronous over synchronous communication which improves working hours flexibility.
column67: I haven't seen any question directly addressing giving and receiving feedback among members of the team on one-to-one communication, and I think this can be sometimes be challenging for peaople working together.

column67: Being the only person that knows about a topic, does present significant challenges. My team has in 90% of the cases no idea what my code does, and if there are issues, I have to resolve them on my own and have no one to bounce ideas off of. This is very bad for my personal morale, and has lead to a lack of motivation on several occasions.
Constant changing priorities. More service related tasks then development related tasks such as an email coming through asking for a report rather then working on the long term goals or tasks.
Preferred employees are chosen to grow in hierarchy. For example german people will always choose for manager/leadership another german person.
column68: I am curious what will happen with this data. Will be curious to see the results

column35: By use of MS Teams.
column37: Better sync on progress, better planning and resolving impediments.

column34: No persistent chatroom"just" work meetings with topic based discussion, no "idea" / "brainstorming" meetings, no creative thinking, group solutions
column36: Unclear who takes action first (or at all) - who responds to an urgent email, who restarts the system that crashedThe team itself is hard to grasp
column67: Hard to keep track of junior team members. Hard to know how much guidance they need. Heavily depends on how fast they ask for help on their own.Hard to form some kind of team spirit; successes are hard to celebrate. Basically everything needs to be done more "consciously" - be it asking for help, offering help, giving feedback, just talking about whats happening, ...Some of these things feel kind of "weird"/"set up" in real life for some people already; doing them virtually and with sending out calendar invites for them feels even more weird. But leaving out these events for establishing some social glue brings lots of new problems in the long run.
